clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Nuchal Ligament Calcification on Cervical Function in Patients With Neck Pain
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Nuchal Ligament Calcification on Cervical Function in Patients With Neck Pain

brief_summary.textblock:
Ossification of nuchal ligament often observed in patient with chronic neck pain, previous study showed ossification of nuchal ligament was associated with cervical spondylosis and radiculopathy. Patient with chronic neck pain was divided into two groups according to the presence of ossification of nuchal ligament on cervical radiographic images.
This study is to evaluate and compare the neck function including range of motion, neck strength and pressure pain threshold, radiography characteristics and functional disability between two groups.

primary_outcome.measure: Degrees of cervical range of motion
primary_outcome.description: active range of motion in flexion, extension,lateral bending and rotation direction with Cervical Range of Motion (CROM) instrument

primary_outcome.measure: Angles of cervical lordotic curve at C2-C7 on cervical x-ray
primary_outcome.time_frame: within one week after first visit
primary_outcome.description: measured by both modified Cobb method and Harrison posterior tangent method at C2-C7 in every participants

primary_outcome.measure: Scores of functional disability as a measure of effects of neck pain on daily living
primary_outcome.description: neck disability index (NDI) with 10-item scaled questionnaire

primary_outcome.measure: The values of neck flexor, extensor, lateral bending and rotation strength
The values of pressure pain threshold as a measure of participants' pain sensitivity
primary_outcome.description: Pressure gauge algometer was applied to bilateral upper trapezius

arm_group.description: check neck function, radiography characteristics and complete functional disability questionnaire

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient with neck pain and stiffness last for more than 1 month
Exclusion Criteria:
- cervical trauma or fracture in 3 months
- evidence of cervical spine instability
- rheumatoid cervical spondylopathy
- previous cervical surgery
- head and neck cancer
- previous radiotherapy over neck and surrounding
- those complicated with myelopathy
- contraindication to radiography like pregnant woman
